metadata.title: Connecting the Dots: Hypotheses Generation by Leveraging Semantic Shifts Supplementary Material A Potentiality of DBpedia as a Cross-domain and Cross-lingual Resource

body_text.text: The DBpedia version 2016-10 consists of 134 localised versions [2] that have been extracted from the corresponding language edition of Wikipedia [9] . Table  1 summarises the basic statistics of few localised DBpedia editions in the release 3.8 [9] . Overall, the English version of DBpedia include more instances compared to other language editions. The second and third largest localised editions are German and French respectively. Table 2 illustrates how DBpedia entities can be mapped in its localised versions for the main topics of the golden test cases using DBpedia's French language edition.
In this section, the preprocessing tasks outlined in Table 3 are discussed in detail.

In a typical LBD setting, MeSH or UMLS is employed for concept extraction [21] . Nevertheless, this is limiting as these resources only facilitate medicalrelated concept extraction. To this end, we utilised DBpedia concepts (entity names) that was originally acquired from Wikipedia articles for concept identification. The reason for selecting DBpedia 1 as the main resource [1] for concept extraction is due to its dynamic and fast-growing nature [22] . Therefore, new knowledge is constantly added to DBpedia irrespective of the domain, which makes DBpedia an up-to-date resource [25] . The reason for selecting DBpedia concepts as the main data unit of concept extraction is that it represents Wikipedia article titles which is well-formed and succinct that resembles a term in a conventional thesaurus [11] . We considered the entire English DBpedia concepts as our initial vocabulary. The concept extraction was performed by mapping the longest contiguous sequence of tokens in a sentence with the corresponding concept in the vocabulary. The extracted concepts are stored in its original order of the sentence to preserve the contextual information that is useful in semantic shifts analysis.

In a typical research setting of LBD knowledge discovery, the synonyms are identified using medical resources such as MeSH and UMLS [21] . As an alternative for synonyms identification in cross-domain and cross-lingual manner, we used the property "is dbo:wikiPageRedirects of" in DBpedia. Redirects are a special type of articles used in DBpedia that are originated from Wikipedia to group equivalent concepts of the main article to ensure that only one article exists for a particular concept [25] . In addition to alternative terms, redirects also handle abbreviations (e.g., Insulin-like growth factor 1 vs. IGF-1 ) and spelling variations (e.g., raynaud disease vs. raynaud's disease). For example, consider the concept Raynaud disease where DBpedia is currently having nearly 30 synonymous terms 2 . We used such synonyms terms in our Query Expansion phase to ensure that all the relevant articles related to the input topics A and C are retrieved to ensure the richness of our local topic coverage. In other words, the synonymous terms are connected using or operator to devise the expanded search query that is used to obtain the query specific local literature.

Even though LBD can be applied in a cross-disciplinary manner, the user may only be interested in retrieving implicit associations in sub-domains of a single main domain. For example, analysing novel associations of Raynaud disease and Fish oil literature in Medical domain. In such situations, the extracted concepts needed to be filtered by using concepts only in the selected main domain.

In a typical LBD setting the popular medical-related controlled vocabulary terminologies such as MeSH or UMLS will be used [21] . To facilitate domain generalisability, we exploited DBpedia's hierarchical categories. The DBpedia category structure which is inherited from Wikipedia is a directed acyclic graph where numerous categorisation-schemes coexist simultaneously by forming a thematically organised thesaurus [25] . Each DBpedia article or category is assigned to more than one category. We exploited the following two DBpedia properties; dct:subject and skos:broader to detect whether a concept belong to the interested domain. The property dct:subject denotes the belonging of a concept/topic to a category whereas the property skos:broader denotes the broader category of a given category [16] . Fig. 2 exemplify how the above discussed two properties form the structure of topics and categories in DBpedia.

We exploited the property paths to route through this topic-category graph structure and to elicit the domain-related terminology. For example, consider the DBpedia graph snippet of the concept Raynaud disease and its related categories as shown in Fig. 3 . It is clear that most of the immediate categories of Raynaud disease (i.e. via dct:subject property) quickly reaches (i.e. using less number of hops) the main domain concept Medicine via skos:broader property. Therefore, we decide a concept as a domain-related terminology if majority of its immediate categories reaches the domain concept with less than or equal to 8 hops. From our empirical analysis we observed that concepts such as Operant conditioning 3 (even though not directly relevant to Medical domain), have majority of distant categories that reaches the main domain concept Medicine. To avoid inclusion of such concepts as discipline-related terminology, we also impose a rule that the concept should have at least one immediate category that reaches the domain concept with less than or equal to 4 hops.
body_text.section: Fig. 2. DBpedia topics and category structure

body_text.text: The LBD literature typically favour concepts with high granularity, thus remove less granular terms as a preprocessing step. Typically, MeSH hierarchy levels are considered to identify the granularity of a concept [21] . Notwithstanding, DBpedia category structure is not in a tree structure, but as a directed acyclic graph (as discussed in Discipline-related terminology section). Hence, employing a hierarchical level filtering as in MeSH is not possible in DBpedia. However, from our empirical analysis, we observed that less granular terms have high indegree page links. Therefore, we removed concepts that have more than 1000 in-degree page links as a preprocessing step of the input literature.
This section exemplify the six semantic shift measures used in the main paper.

Global Semantic Shift: This measure quantifies the linguistic drift of a concept by analysing how far a concept has moved in the semantic space between two consecutive time-slices. To facilitate this, we measure the cosine distance of the concept's word vector w i in the aligned vector spaces modelled at time t and t+1 as illustrated in Fig. 4 (a) . This measure is sensitive to subtle usage drifts and other global effects [4] .

Local Semantic Shift: This measure focuses on semantic change at local scale by considering the concept's (w i ) nearest semantic neighbours in two consecutive time slices t and t+1 as depicted in Fig. 4 (b) . Therefore, this measure is sensitive to the concept's paradigmatic relations and less concerned with global shifts in syntagmatic contexts [4] . Pairwise Semantic Displacement This measure intends to capture how the concept's (w i ) semantic similarity changes across time relatively to the A (w A ) and C (w C ) topics as shown in Fig. 5 (a) . Thus, this measure facilitates to verify whether the concept implies a growing semantic similarity towards A and C topics.

Pairwise Distance Proximity The purpose of this measure is to identify if the concept's (w i ) temporal trajectory is leaning towards to a close proximity to both A (w A ) and C (w C ) topics. The spur to this measure is that LBD seeks latent conceptual bridges that connects A and C, thus, the concept's trajectory should inclines towards both the input topics. Note that in Fig. 5 (b) w j is only favouring w C at time t+1.

Neighbourhood Semantic Displacement The only difference of the this measure compared to Pairwise Semantic Displacement measure is that it involves the recent core meaning of the input topics A (w A ) and C (w C ) in the calculation as denoted in Fig. 6 (a) . Thus, this measure captures how well the concept (w i ) make semantic relationships not only with the input two topics, but also with its recent core meaning. Therefore, this measure provides the opportunity to evaluate the need of assessing the semantic neighbourhood of the input topics in LBD context. Neighbourhood Semantic Proximity This measure extends the idea of Pairwise Distance Proximity measure by incorporating the recent neighbourhood of topic A (w A ) and C (w C ) (see Fig. 6 (b) ). More specifically, this measure verifies whether the concept's (w i ) temporal trajectory inclines not just to topic A and C, but also to their semantic neighbours.

In our experiments, we divided the MEDLINE dataset 4 into 1 year time unit slices (e.g., 1960, 1961 and so on). In each time-slice we trained a SGNS model where we set the dimensionality of the word embeddings to 300 and window size to 5. Same as prior studies in LBD (see [21] for more details), we selected title and abstract for the analysis. The parameters used for each of the proposed semantic shift measures are summarised in Table 4 . We considered 100 nearest neighbours of each local topic to measure the local semantic shift (i.e. K = 100) Pairwise semantic displacement -Pairwise distance proximity
We considered 5 as the penalising factor of the distance differences of topic A and C (i.e. β = 5) Neighbourhood semantic dispalcement

We considered the constant neighbours of topic A and C over 5 years. To compute the constant neighbours that represent the core meaning we considered 500 nearest neighbours of topic A and C (i.e. W = 5 and K = 500) Neighbourhood distance proximity

In summary, each local topic is represented by six temporal trajectories that were calculated using the proposed six semantic shifts; Global semantic shift, Local semantic shift, Pairwise semantic displacement, Pairwise distance proximity, Neighbourhood semantic displacement, and Neighbourhood distance proximity. The derived trajectories were analysed using two types of models namely; .., s RSS-S (w T i )) where y is the first occurrence of w i in the dataset, the following features were extracted from the temporal trajectory; minimum, maximum, mean, median, standard deviation, variance, length, sum, count above mean, count below mean and trajectory trend (using the slope of ordinary least-squares approximation. i.e. m in f(x) = mx + b)). We employed RandomForest as the classifier of the FTM models. For all the experiments, stratified 10-fold cross-validation was used to ensure that the folds are created by preserving the sample percentage of each class. The knowledge linkages' estimated probability of being new knowledge is recorded when they are in the testing slice. The same setup was used for the ARROWSMITH baseline that uses seven features in its LBD process (see Section E.3).

We employed a sequential LSTM model comprised of a hidden and an output layer as our DTM model. For instance, Fig. 7 depicts the schematic overview of the DTM-D model that uses ISS and RSS temporal trajectories as its input. Similar to the FTM model, stratified 10-fold cross-validation was used for all the experiments and the estimated probabilities of each knowledge linkage when it is in testing slice was obtained. Regarding the rest of the hyper-parameters, we employed adam optimizer with 100 epochs and 500 batch size.

We considered all the five standard golden test cases in LBD discipline to evaluate the efficiency of the proposed model. The importance of these test cases in hypotheses generation setting is that each topic in the test cases are complementary but disjoint. For instance, consider Fig. 8 (a) that depicts the isolation of the two knowledge areas of Fish oil and Raynaud's disease test case (i.e. test case (1) in our experiments). Fig. 8 (b) shows how the two knowledge fragments got connected from the initial LBD research of Swanson.

Thus far, the most objective and commonly used evaluation technique used in the discipline is time-sliced evaluation where the literature is divided into two segments namely; pre-cut-off segment and post-cut segment [21] . The proposed model and baselines are run on the literature in pre-cut-off segment. Subsequently, the discovered knowlege linkages are checked in post-cut-off segment. The validity of a discovered knowledge linkage is decided if it is present (cooccurrence) in post-cut-off segment and absent in pre-cut-off segment. Table 5 summarises the details of pre-cut-off and post-cut-off segments of the five golden [13] test cases. Same as previous LBD studies [7, 26] , equation 1 was employed to rank the ground truth conceptual bridge k for the given two topics of interest (A, and C ).

where #(i,j ) is number of times concepts i and j co-occur and #(i ) = j #(i,j ). Similar to the prior LBD studies [7, 26] , a postprocessing step was performed to remove the check-tags from the ground truth. For this purpose, the highly frequent terms (i.e. the bottom 0.05% of the ranked list obtained from equation 1) and ambiguate terms (i.e. using DBpedia property: dbo:wikiPageDisambiguates) were removed automatically from the ground truth. The statistics of global and local corpora of the five golden test cases are summarised in Table 6 .

Similar to previous LBD research [7, 26, 8] , we considered the following eight baseline algorithms to compare the performance. -Dynamic Embeddings (DE): Dynamic embeddings refer to a recent temporal LBD algorithm that uses diachronic word embeddings [26] . How our model differs from this work is discussed in detail in Section 1 of the manuscript.

-ARROWSMITH (AR): This is the most popular and well-maintained LBD system that was initiated by the pioneers of the discipline [12] . The system uses seven features to decide the potentiality of the knowledge linkages. These features include both global and local properties (see [23] for the details of the features).

-Mutual Information (MI): Mutual information is widely employed to measure the dependencies between variables. In LBD context it is used to calculate the degree of closeness of the conceptual bridges to the selected topics as demonstrated in [10] .

-Apriori algorithm (AR): Apriori which is an algorithm of association rules mining uses two important measures namely; support and confidence that has been used to rank the new connections as described in [6] .

-Term Frequency and Inverse Document Frequency (TI): TF-IDF is a popular metric that represents the importance of a concept to a document in the corpus and widely used in LBD literature to detect bridge concepts [7] .

-Literature Cohesiveness (COH): Literature Cohesiveness is a metric that measures the cohesion of literature to differentiate the new knowledge. This measure was proposed by the pioneers in the LBD discipline [20] . Later, this measure was included as a feature of the ARROWSMITH system [23] .
-Static Embeddings (SE): Static embeddings refers to word embeddings that are generated without integrating any temporal analysis where the bridge terms are ranked using cosine similarity [7] .

-Static Networks (SN): Static networks incorporates the analysis of co-occurrence networks by considering the aggregation of three centrality measures; degree centrality, betweenness centrality and closeness centrality [24] . The selected three centrality measures are the widely used micro graph measures in the discipline [3] .

In this section, we report the complete results obtained for each of the golden test cases (see Table 5 ). Similar to prior LBD studies [7] , we used the two standard evaluation measures used in information retrieval tasks; precision@k and Mean Average Precision@k to quantify the results. Table 7 summarises the Precision@k results for all the five golden datasets. The k value is gradually increased from 10 to 100. Table 8 includes the Mean Average Precision@k results obtained for the five golden test cases.
